2.  Facility Description and Regulated Substances Handled
The primary activities at the New Martinsville facility are towards the manufacture of polyurethane intermediates, coatings intermediates and thermoplastics.  Products include polyethers, prepolymers, polyesters and thermoplastic urethanes.  In addition, aromatic isocyanides, and hydrochloric acid are received for reprocessing and repackaging.  The New Martinsville facility uses or stores four of the RMP listed chemicals on the site as of December 1, 2012.  Of the four chemicals covered, three are raw materials and one is a finished product.  All four chemicals were modeled using worst case release parameters as a screening exercise to determine the worst case scenario for the facility.    The worst case scenario chemical for the New Martinsville site is ethylene oxide.  The alternative scenarios in order of potential off-site impact are ethylene oxide, propylene oxide and ethylene diamine and toluene diisocyanate.

em consists of employee emergency response teams scheduled on each rotating shift.  There are 110 emergency response team members.  They receive 16 to 80 hours of on-site training annually with some disciplines receiving off-site training as well in specialized subjects, such as firefighting, rescue, incident command and Hazmat.  An Incident Command organization provides secondary support and is staffed by Technical and Managerial Personnel.  The Incident Command Team's main function is to assist and advise the Emergency Response Teams and communicate with outside agencies.  The plant belongs to an industrial mutual aid group called NORIMAC (Northern Ohio River Industrial Mutual Aid Council) that provides mutual aid between the various industries, government agencies, and service organizations in the area.  Community warning sirens are placed in residential areas within 2 miles of the plant and have been in operation, as part of the CAER program, for more than twenty years.

ase Scenario for the Facility
The worst case release scenario for the New Martinsville facility is the rupture of the ethylene oxide storage tank into a dike that is 1100 square feet and 12 feet deep.  Because of the low storage temperature, the release to the atmosphere occurs through evaporation from a pool.   Through use of dispersion modeling (RMP*Comp), the endpoint distance is 1.8 miles and reaches offsite receptors.  This release assumes no mitigation other than containment in a dike.

4.  Alternative Release Scenarios
Alternative scenarios were developed for all of the RMP chemicals. The alternative scenario for ethylene oxide has the largest potential impact distance of the group. In this scenario it is assumed that a leak develops during the unloading of a rail car.  Under typical weather conditions the distance to the endpoint is 1.0 miles and reaches offsite receptors.

5.  Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps
The New Martinsville Plant complies with all elements of the OSHA PSM Rule and the EPA RMP Rule.  There are safety procedures, standard operation emergency procedures, accident investigations, hot work and line opening permits, extensive training programs, on-site emergency response teams, vessel inspection programs, and experienced personnel both in the salaried and hourly workforce.  Bayer MaterialScience LLC is an active member of the ACC Ethylene Oxide Safety Panel that deals with ethylene oxide safety issues on an industry-wide basis.

6.  Five Year Accident History
There have been no releases in the past five years that had off-site consequences.  A liquid TDI release within the plant resulted in an OSHA Recordable Accident in 2008.  The release totaled 10 pounds.  At the New Martinsville facility, there has never been any offsite impact resulting from the release of chemicals listed in the rule.

Executive Summary for the Risk Management Rule

1.  Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies
Bayer MaterialScience LLC is committed to the principles of Responsible Care which stress operating in a safe and environmentally correct manner. Management systems are in place to assure all facilities are complying with these principles.  There are Corporate Engineering Standards and Health, Environment, and Safety Guidelines which address every aspect of Risk Management from the design of intrinsically safe processes, to the use of risk assessment, to incident tracking and program audits. Bayer MaterialScience LLC is headquartered in Pittsburgh PA and is a subsidiary of Bayer AG, which is headquartered in Leverkusen, Germany.  Bayer MaterialScience LLC has its own company structure, policies and procedures which are consistent with those of the holding company, but are customized to meet local regulations and standards.  Bayer AG has established guidelines for Responsible Care in Environmental Protection and Safety, which include a Directive for Process and Plant Safety that all Bayer facilities world-wide are expected to follow.  It provides guidance for safe process design and operation.

In the US, Bayer MaterialScience LLC is an active member of the American Chemistry Council's Responsible Care Initiative.  Bayer has implemented all seven codes of management practice.  Bayer MaterialScience LLC has a Health, Safety, Environment, and Quality Policy which states that it is the company's responsibility to protect the environment and the health and safety of its employees, customers and communities.  This is a primary responsibility, of equal importance to any other business objective.
